These statements aren't necessarily contradictory. In the first case, investors are bearish because they anticipate selling in the future (because all the interested buyers have been scooped up). In this case, the bearish sentiment is based on fundamentals (low valuations/interest rates) as well as supply-demand projections (low interest rate means less investment in equities will occur). In the other case, the bearish sentiment is based solely on supply and demand (lower interest rates implies lower demand) and not on fundamentals (lower valuations). 
In the first case, there may be many investors waiting to dump their stocks or bonds in the future, making it difficult for new investors to enter the market. In the second case, however, the low interest rates may be encouraging new investors to enter the market since they can borrow at lower rates, making the potential return on investment more attractive.

The earlier systems, like Boeing's Conexxion, used a special kind of antenna called a phased - array antenna. That antenna sent radio signals out, then received the signals from the receiving antenna. With Conexxion, the signals were sent and received all at once (like one big group of friends taking turns to speak to each other at a party). With the new system, the sending and receiving are now done independently (songs can be played separately from each other and people can chat on the phone).
In this system (called DIMMS), the sending and the receiving are done using the same antenna (like the two of you talking on the same phone cord). That means you can see how far apart they are, because the distance from your receiver to a distant tower (that you don't see) is the same as the distance from the tower to a nearby transmitting antenna. Information extraction (IE) is the task of automatically extracting structured information from unstructured and/or semi-structured machine-readable documents and other sources, usually by text processing or natural language processing. In other words, it involves taking information from texts or other data sources and organizing and categorizing it into a meaningful format that computer systems can use. 

Information extraction can be used for many purposes, including sentiment analysis, content categorization, and content analysis. For example, in the context of a hotel, information extraction can be used to extract customer reviews or feedback, categorize them into positive or negative sentiments, and provide insights or recommendations for improving the hotel's services. 

Follow up exercises: 
1. How can information extraction be used in the hospitality industry? 
2. What are some challenges or limitations of information extraction? 
3. Can you provide an example of how information extraction can be used in the context of public relations for a hotel?

One of the depth cues your brain uses to determine where things are located is called binocular disparity. Binocular disparity works by comparing the image of the world made by each of your eyes. Your brain can then compare these two images to help you determine the position of an object. The binocular disparity is measured by the difference in distance between your eyes.
Because there is a difference in binocular disparity between each of the eyes, the farther apart your eyes are, the greater the disparity is between the images. In the case of 3d movies such as "The Martian," your left eye and your right eye have different images of the world. This difference in binocular disparity means that your brain will have more difficulty perceiving 3-dimensions than if your eyes were looking at the same image.
The main problem with this concept is that the images your brain sees are coming from two different locations. In other words, the same object can have two different images in two different eyes. This

When you hear about the " Ninth Circuit, " the rest of the phrase is " United States Circuit Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. " There are actually nine Federal Circuits, and the " Ninth " Circuit is a little bit larger than other Circuits – more about that below. But it's important to understand that the " Ninth " Circuit is the Court of Appeals that covers the states of Arizona, California, Idaho, Montana, Nevada, Oregon, and Washington – as well as some tribal courts in states like Alaska, Colorado, Hawaii, North Dakota, and Wyoming. The " Ninth Circuit, " as it was formally founded during March 5, 1891, is still the Circuit with the greatest number of Federal judgeships among the nine Federal Circuits, and most of the judgeships have long been filled by judges appointed by President Donald Trump in 2017 – although there are nine Judicial seats left in the " Ninth Circuit " which have yet to be filled. Not necessarily. People with poor eyesight could have had a functioning role in most organized societies even back in the caveman days. Rather than go out and look for food, they could have stayed behind to gather and cook food for the rest of the tribe, or to perform other important tasks that did not require good eyesight. If our primitive ancestors with poor eyesight were around, then so too were our more sophisticated ancestors with impaired vision who lived in the era of the Renaissance, the Enlightenment, and the Information Age.
When thinking about this issue from a scientific perspective, it actually doesn't make a lot of sense to think of vision as a "sickness" that needs to be cured. After all, vision is a biological attribute which has existed since the dawn of life itself. Evolution has already provided us with numerous adaptations that allow for the use of vision to overcome various limitations, and there is very little evidence that any of us are missing a critical "need" for the development

How accurate is Implied Volatility in predicting future moves? How would you measure this? If the implied volatility says that there's a 1% chance of a 10% move against the S&P 500 on June 18, is that the same level of accuracy as when the S&P 500 falls 10% on January 1? In the short-term, these are very similar moves, yet the implied volatility isn't nearly as accurate. This is because implied volatility represents investor sentiment around a future event – not the actual outcome of that event.

These all seem above 5yo level, I 'll take a stab... Electricity is generated by spinning a magnet next to a wire. As the magnet speeds, it generates a changing magnetic field, with the strongest field around the poles and the weakest on the body, generating an electric current in the wire.
For the magnet, the pole which is closest to the wire generates the strongest field and hence the smallest magnetic radius of separation. You can see this by spinning your hand with a compass, and observing where the needles align.

Enriched Uranium is comprised of the Uranium-235 isotope. If you don't know what an isotope is, it's the variation of the chemical composition of an element due to differences in the neutron count in its nucleus. Uranium-233 has a neutron count that is 1 neutron more than the Uranium-235 isotope. The difference in the neutron count has profound consequences in nuclear fission. In general, when a nuclear weapon is detonated, each of the Uranium-235 atoms produces two free neutrons that can go on to split other Uranium-235 atoms. A Uranium-233 atom will also produce neutrons as it fissions, but only one of those neutrons will go on to split another Uranium-233 atom. Very interesting question! I did a little calculation to determine how much data we're talking about here. So I took a random 1min video from an mp4, with the file size of 1 MB. A file the size of a megabyte is 1 million bits, and a bit is one single bit of information in binary. So on a 10 Mbps link, one million bits can be read and uploaded at one time, which means around 9.3 seconds to download that one minute video. The actual download speed is, with the link being slower than 10 Mbps, around 7 seconds!!
But if you have a 10 Gbps link, then you would only need 1.73 seconds, which roughly is half the time that the same video would take to be downloaded using the same link at 100Mbps. So even at this low-speed link we see a significant difference in download time (and thus file transfer speed)!

It would be very unusual (and very erroneous) to have a company's stock be included in the Long Term Investments on the balance sheet. It would be even more unusual to have its debt in Long-Term Investments. Thus the only two ways debt can wind up being reflected as long-term investments are if the company owns real estate (at cost, with proceeds from the sale reinvested) or if the debt is securitized and is included in the debt held by other holders category.
For debt to wind up on the balance sheet as a long-term investment would require that the debt be rolled over more than one year. As we explain later in Chapter 8: Balance Sheet, it is unusual, but not impossible, that a company is able to rollover debt more than once.

Neuroimaging is the use of quantitative (computational) techniques to study the structure and function of the central nervous system, developed as an alternative to animal experimentation. It has revolutionized the knowledge of human brain organization and the diseases that afflict it. In clinical neuropsychology, the two main imaging techniques currently used in research are positron emission tomography (PET) and functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI). PET has been employed for many years in studies of brain structure and disease, while fMRI is the relatively new field of imaging that is revolutionizing the study of higher cognitive and affective processes.
The two main types of imaging in neuropsychology are:
Functional cerebral blood flow (fMRI) and Positron Emission Tomography (PET):
Functional cerebral blood flow (fMRI) is a technique used for measuring how much blood is being transported either into or out of various brain regions and can show how active these regions are during specific tasks
